chapterMeaning: The Yoga of Liberation through Renunciation
sanskrit: सर्वधर्मान्परित्यज्य मामेकं शरणं व्रज । अहं त्वा सर्वपापेभ्यो मोक्षयिष्यामि मा शुचः ॥
transliteration: sarva-dharmān parityajya mām ekaṁ śaraṇaṁ vraja | ahaṁ tvā sarva-pāpebhyo mokṣayiṣyāmi mā śucaḥ ||
translation: Abandoning all dharmas (duties and religious practices), take refuge in Me alone. I shall liberate you from all sins; do not grieve.
commentary:
This verse is considered the crown jewel (charama śloka) of the Bhagavad Gita, representing the ultimate teaching of Krishna to Arjuna. After elaborating on various paths of yoga, types of knowledge, renunciation, and the nature of dharma throughout the eighteen chapters, Krishna now delivers the essence of all spiritual instruction: complete surrender to the Divine. The phrase 'sarva-dharmān parityajya' does not advocate abandoning one's duties, but rather transcending attachment to the fruits of all actions and ritualistic practices by taking absolute refuge in the Supreme.

Krishna's assurance 'ahaṁ tvā sarva-pāpebhyo mokṣayiṣyāmi' provides the ultimate consolation to the spiritual aspirant. This promise of liberation from all sins addresses the fundamental human anxiety about past karmas and their consequences. The Lord takes complete responsibility for the devotee who surrenders wholeheartedly, removing all karmic burdens accumulated through countless lifetimes. The final instruction 'mā śucaḥ' (do not grieve) dispels all fear and doubt, encouraging complete trust in divine grace.

This verse synthesizes the entire teaching of the Gita by emphasizing bhakti (devotion) as the supreme path. While the Gita honors karma yoga, jñāna yoga, and dhyāna yoga, this ultimate instruction reveals that loving surrender to Krishna transcends all other methods. It represents the culmination of spiritual evolution where the individual soul recognizes its eternal relationship with the Supreme and takes unconditional refuge, thereby attaining moksha (liberation). This teaching has inspired countless devotees throughout history and remains the cornerstone of bhakti traditions.
speaker: Krishna
